utterances: (Soundbite of laughter)
I hate the comfort zone.
Let's put it that way.
The rap on Taymor is that she's a spendthrift whose artistic ambitions are out of control.
Jesse Green says he was struck when he spoke with her by how little commercial considerations concerned her.

She spoke about combining her interests in Greek myth and world theater and puppetry and comic books and all of these things - which were very high-minded and, I have to admit, although they were very interesting, one wondered how they could ever possibly come together in something as tawdry and lowdown as a Broadway show.
(Soundbite of stage play, ""Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark"")
(Soundbite of song, ""Boy Falls from the Sky"")
(As Peter Parker/Spider-Man) (Singing) You can fly too high and get too close to the sun.
See how the boy falls from the sky.
And while Taymor tinkered and the New York State Department of Labor ran safety inspections, the critics silently sat on the sidelines waiting for a constantly delayed opening night.
Finally, they said enough.
Jeremy Gerard is theater critic for Bloomberg News.
Julie Taymor was talking about how she was going to create this great American myth about Spider-Man as this iconic figure, a real American kind of superhero.
And what we got was gibberish.
Most of the other critics agreed.
Ben Brantley in the New York Times was particularly harsh.
He referred to the show's sheer ineptitude, but he says ultimately...
I think that if anything kills ""Spider-Man,"" it'll be word-of-mouth.
But the evening after his review - and all the others - came out, word-of-mouth was, if not stellar, pretty good.
Karen Sass from Yonkers, New York brought her two boys to see the show.
We had one little glitch at the end, but my kids enjoyed it.
I would highly recommend it.
They need to cut about 15 minutes out of the second act, but it's perfect.
What did you like best about it?
Oh, the flying sequences were just amazing.
And this song, ""The Party,"" is from the new album by Regina Spektor.
It's the latest in a line of critically-acclaimed and successful pop records with her trademark vocal curly-cues and contagious piano melodies.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""THE PARTY"")
(Singing) And we're coming out right along to sing my new song.
Spektor came to NPR to talk about her latest release, ""What We Saw From the Cheap Seats,"" but I couldn't resist asking her about one of the first public radio interviews she did back in 2005.
Regina Spektor is our musical guest.
It was for the program, The Next Big Thing, at WNYC and we took a listen together.
I just wrote a song last night and I don't know if I remember it, but I really want to remember it.
OK.
Me, too.
So I'll try.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Wow, that's so slow.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""FIDELITY"")
(Singing) I never loved nobody fully.
Always one foot on the ground.
What's it like hearing that now?
It's weird.
It's such a mindtrip.
First of all, I completely forgot, completely forgot that that actually happened like that.
Wow.
And, at the time in the interview, you talked about writing that song the night before and staying up until 3:30 in the morning and hoping you weren't bothering the neighbors.
(Unintelligible) hear it in my voice.
Yeah.
But you also said that you never write songs down.
And is that still true?
Yeah, unfortunately.
I try to be better now, at least about recording little things because sometimes I still have, like, things just disappear.
You know, you always think, oh, I'll never forget that.
That's so obvious.
And then, of course, you forget it completely.
That sounds scary to me, as a fan, when you say disappear.
I feel like there are lost Regina Spektor songs somewhere.
There's so many.
There's tremendous amounts.

I mean, I actually - I am so lucky because, almost from the beginning, people would record the shows and I just - I am so thankful to them, first of all, for taking the time and putting it up online and sharing it with other listeners.
But also mainly with myself because there are so many songs that I would not know how to play and it gives me such relief to know that they're somewhere.

On this album, ""What We Saw From the Cheap Seats,"" it sounds like you have songs that span a couple of years, like just because we're listening to the Regina Spektor album now, it doesn't mean that these are songs that have come from the last year of your life or the last...
Yeah.
Oh, yeah.
No. It's more than a couple of years.
I mean, there are songs on this record that must be 10 years old or more.
Like what?
Probably ""Ne Me Quitte Pas,"" which on the record, is called ""Don't Leave Me.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""NE ME QUITTE PAS - DON'T LEAVE ME"")
(Singing) (unintelligible).
This song is one of the songs that I released on my record called ""Songs."" It was self-released record and I didn't really know anybody in the music industry at that point, really.
I was out of college and I was playing a lot in bars and cafes.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""NE ME QUITTE PAS - DON'T LEAVE ME"")
(Singing) (Unintelligible).
I met this really awesome guy who became a really good friend of mine, Joe Mendleson.
He would introduce me to music.
He played me - like, for the first time I ever heard Kate Bush or Peter Gabriel or a full Elton John record was all through him and...
I like that you said a full Elton John record.
Well, because you know - it is true.
Well, because you know what it is with me?

I'm so backwards in the fact that, like, a lot of the time, I'll know somebody's music, but I won't connect the name of the person to the music, you know, because I sort of felt kind of in that immigrant bubble where it was hard for me to kind of connect the dots.
